#Text=Marie was busy , turning over the contents of a drawer , as she answered ,
#Text=“ Well , of course , by and by , Eva , you will have other things to think of besides reading the Bible round to servants .
#Text=Not but that is very proper ; I ’ve done it myself , when I had health .
#Text=But when you come to be dressing and going into company , you wo n’t have time .
#Text=See here ! ” she added , “ these jewels I ’m going to give you when you come out .
#Text=I wore them to my first ball .
#Text=I can tell you , Eva , I made a sensation . ”
#Text=Eva took the jewel-case , and lifted from it a diamond necklace .
#Text=Her large , thoughtful eyes rested on them , but it was plain her thoughts were elsewhere .
#Text=“ How sober you look child ! ” said Marie .
#Text=“ Are these worth a great deal of money , mamma ? ”
#Text=“ To be sure , they are .
#Text=Father sent to France for them .
#Text=They are worth a small fortune . ”
#Text=“ I wish I had them , ” said Eva , “ to do what I pleased with ! ”
#Text=“ What would you do with them ? ”
#Text=“ I ’d sell them , and buy a place in the free states , and take all our people there , and hire teachers , to teach them to read and write . ”
#Text=Eva was cut short by her mother ’s laughing .
#Text=“ Set up a boarding-school !
#Text=Would n’t you teach them to play on the piano , and paint on velvet ? ”
#Text=“ I ’d teach them to read their own Bible , and write their own letters , and read letters that are written to them , ” said Eva , steadily .
#Text=“ I know , mamma , it does come very hard on them that they ca n’t do these things .
#Text=Tom feels it --
#Text=Mammy does , -- a great many of them do .
#Text=I think it ’s wrong . ”
#Text=“ Come , come , Eva ; you are only a child ! You do n’t know anything about these things , ” said Marie ;
#Text=“ besides , your talking makes my head ache . ”
#Text=Marie always had a headache on hand for any conversation that did not exactly suit her .
#Text=Eva stole away ; but after that , she assiduously gave Mammy reading lessons .
#Text=CHAPTER XXIII
#Text=Henrique
#Text=About this time , St. Clare ’s brother Alfred , with his eldest son , a boy of twelve , spent a day or two with the family at the lake .
#Text=No sight could be more singular and beautiful than that of these twin brothers .
#Text=Nature , instead of instituting resemblances between them , had made them opposites on every point ; yet a mysterious tie seemed to unite them in a closer friendship than ordinary .
#Text=They used to saunter , arm in arm , up and down the alleys and walks of the garden .

#Text=Augustine , with his blue eyes and golden hair , his ethereally flexible form and vivacious features ; and Alfred , dark-eyed , with haughty Roman profile , firmly-knit limbs , and decided bearing .

#Text=They were always abusing each other ’s opinions and practices , and yet never a whit the less absorbed in each other ’s society ; in fact , the very contrariety seemed to unite them , like the attraction between opposite poles of the magnet .

#Text=Henrique , the eldest son of Alfred , was a noble , dark-eyed , princely boy , full of vivacity and spirit ; and , from the first moment of introduction , seemed to be perfectly fascinated by the spirituelle graces of his cousin Evangeline .
#Text=Eva had a little pet pony , of a snowy whiteness .

#Text=It was easy as a cradle , and as gentle as its little mistress ; and this pony was now brought up to the back verandah by Tom , while a little mulatto boy of about thirteen led along a small black Arabian , which had just been imported , at a great expense , for Henrique .
#Text=Henrique had a boy ’s pride in his new possession ; and , as he advanced and took the reins out of the hands of his little groom , he looked carefully over him , and his brow darkened .
#Text=“ What ’s this , Dodo , you little lazy dog ! you have n’t rubbed my horse down , this morning . ”
#Text=“ Yes , Mas’r , ” said Dodo , submissively ;
#Text=“ he got that dust on his own self . ”
#Text=“ You rascal , shut your mouth ! ” said Henrique , violently raising his riding-whip .
#Text=“ How dare you speak ? ”
#Text=The boy was a handsome , bright-eyed mulatto , of just Henrique ’s size , and his curling hair hung round a high , bold forehead .
#Text=He had white blood in his veins , as could be seen by the quick flush in his cheek , and the sparkle of his eye , as he eagerly tried to speak .
#Text=“ Mas’r Henrique ! -- ” he began .
#Text=Henrique struck him across the face with his riding-whip , and , seizing one of his arms , forced him on to his knees , and beat him till he was out of breath .
#Text=“ There , you impudent dog !
#Text=Now will you learn not to answer back when I speak to you ?
#Text=Take the horse back , and clean him properly .
#Text=I ’ll teach you your place ! ”

#Text=“ Young Mas’r , ” said Tom , “ I specs what he was gwine to say was , that the horse would roll when he was bringing him up from the stable ; he ’s so full of spirits , -- that ’s the way he got that dirt on him ; I looked to his cleaning . ”
#Text=“ You hold your tongue till you ’re asked to speak ! ” said Henrique , turning on his heel , and walking up the steps to speak to Eva , who stood in her riding-dress .
#Text=“ Dear Cousin , I ’m sorry this stupid fellow has kept you waiting , ” he said .
#Text=“ Let ’s sit down here , on this seat till they come .
#Text=What ’s the matter , Cousin ?
#Text=-- you look sober . ”
#Text=“ How could you be so cruel and wicked to poor Dodo ? ” asked Eva .
